journal-title-group.journal-title: bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology

title-group.article-title: Hsp90 shapes adaptation by controlling the fitness consequences of regulatory variation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemical and Systems Biology, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, USA
2Department of Biology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA
3Department of Developmental Biology, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: *To whom correspondence should be addressed: jarosz@stanford.edu

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: The essential stress-responsive chaperone Hsp90 impacts development and adaptation from microbes to humans. Yet despite evidence of its role in evolution, pathogenesis, and oncogenic transformation, the molecular mechanisms by which Hsp90 alters the consequences of mutations remain vigorously debated. Here we exploit the power of nucleotide-resolution genetic mapping in Saccharomyces cerevisiae to uncover more than 1,000 natural variant-to-phenotype associations governed by this molecular chaperone. Strikingly, Hsp90 more frequently modified the phenotypic effects of cis-regulatory variation than variants that altered protein sequence. Moreover, these interactions made the largest contribution to Hsp90-dependent heredity. Nearly all interacting variants—both regulatory and protein-coding—fell within clients of Hsp90 or targets of its direct binding partners. Hsp90 activity affected mutations in evolutionarily young genes, segmental deletions, and heterozygotes, highlighting its influence on variation central to evolutionary novelty. Reconciling the diverse epistatic effects of this chaperone, synthetic transcriptional regulation and reconstructions of natural alleles by genome editing revealed a central role for Hsp90 in regulating the fundamental relationship between activity and phenotype. Our findings establish that non-coding variation is a core driver of Hsp90’s influence on heredity, offering a mechanistic explanation for the chaperone’s strong effects on evolution and development across species.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The genotype-to-phenotype map is constantly remodeled by the environment and in response to stress1, with strong impacts on development as well as in disease and evolution2. The Heat Shock Protein 90 kDa (Hsp90) chaperone has attracted keen interest as a candidate to enact such modifications of the relationship between genotype and phenotype3,4. Hsp90 is a ‘hub of hubs’ with very high genetic and physical connectivity5; its clients6, enriched in kinases, ubiquitin ligases, and other signaling factors7, are likewise highly connected nodes of regulatory networks. As a consequence, Hsp90 influences diverse properties of its client proteins, including protein turnover, steady-state levels, and localization8. Remarkably given its connectivity, the abundance and activity of Hsp90 varies substantially across environmental conditions9. These features endow Hsp90 with the capacity to control the relationship between activity and environmental stress for a network of functionally diverse regulatory proteins.

Hsp90 has profound impacts on the manifestation of the phenotypic effects of genetic variation10–17: modest impairment of Hsp90 function during development in Drosophila melanogaster results in pronounced changes to wings, eyes, and legs15. The lineage specificity of these developmental phenotypes15,18, as well as those observed in other organisms16, suggests that natural polymorphisms determine how Hsp90 shapes the developmental program. Multiple oncogenic17 and drug-resistance10 mutations, as well as other heritable traits in the wild14, depend on Hsp90.

Despite considerable interest and study, how Hsp90 exerts such diverse effects remains uncertain. Prior studies have examined the interactions between Hsp90 and, variously, precise gene deletions19,20, naturally segregating haplotypes21, Fanconi anemia mutations12, variants underlying Mendelian disorders22, and genotypes harboring small numbers of nearly random mutations11. The underlying mutations whose effects are modified by Hsp90 have remained obscure in all but a handful of instances12. Moreover, because of Hsp90’s role as a molecular chaperone, studies that focused on individual variants made the pragmatic assumption that chaperone inhibition primarily impacted coding variation. This gap in knowledge has left a wide gulf between examples of Hsp90’s influence on the capacity of genetic variation to produce phenotypes and scant molecular understanding of how its chaperone activity is linked to these outcomes.

The molecular activity and clientele of Hsp90 are deeply conserved throughout Eukarya23. The advent of genetic mapping approaches in the budding yeast S. cerevisiae that dissect complex traits to their underlying causal variants24,25 thus presents a newfound opportunity to understand the influence of Hsp90 on heredity. Diverse collections of wild isolates26,27, precision genome engineering tools28, and comprehensive knowledge of the genetic and physical interactors of Hsp9029,30, as well as the targets of key clients31,32, make this an ideal venue to understand the mechanisms by which the chaperone network reshapes the genotype-to-phenotype map.

Here, we harness this system to identify thousands of natural polymorphisms throughout the genome whose effects depended strongly on Hsp90 function. Even though Hsp90 is a protein chaperone, these effects were most pronounced for non-coding variation. Nearly all interacting polymorphisms occurred in genes encoding Hsp90 client proteins, clients of co-chaperones, or the targets of regulatory proteins that depend upon Hsp90 to function. We also find evidence for potent modification of evolutionary trajectories by Hsp90: its inhibition altered the phenotypic effects of heterozygous mutations, natural segmental deletions, and mutations in evolutionarily young genes. Our results show that the Hsp90 chaperone network exerts a profound influence on the relationship between activity and phenotype, providing a mechanistic explanation for its potent impact on cis-regulatory variants and for the ubiquity of Hsp90-dependent phenotypes under stress and in development.

sec.title: Nucleotide-resolution mapping of Hsp90-dependent phenotypes
sec.p: To enable genetic mapping with high resolution and sensitivity, we employed ∼15,000 fully genotyped progeny24 from a cross between two wild Saccharomyces cerevisiae parents25,33: RM11, isolated from a California vineyard34, and YJM975, isolated from an immunocompromised patient35. The paralogous genes encoding Hsp90—HSC82 and HSP82—are not polymorphic in the mapping panel (mutations in these genes could confound mapping). To assess the chaperone’s impact on the effects of natural variants [Fig. 1A], we used a potent and specific natural product inhibitor, radicicol36, at a dose that reduced but did not eliminate Hsp90 activity17 [Fig. S1A]. This degree of Hsp90 inhibition did not perturb growth in the absence of stress [Fig. S1B] nor induce a bounce-back heat shock response21 [Fig. S1CD].

We examined the growth of the 15,000-isolate panel in response to diverse environmental perturbations (including alternate carbon sources, toxic metal ions, and DNA-damaging agents, as well as antifungal drugs used clinically and in agriculture) [Supplementary Table S1]. Parallel experiments in the presence of radicicol revealed that Hsp90 inhibition dramatically altered the growth of many F6 diploid progeny [Fig. 1B] and, moreover, did so in a manner that was highly specific to the environment [Fig. S1E]. Coarse genetic mapping readily identify loci with Hsp90-dependent phenotypic effects [Fig. 1C], including the rapamycin-resistance phenotype of a locus centered about the AVO3 (TSC11/RICTOR37) gene [Fig. 1D].

To pinpoint the polymorphisms responsible for Hsp90-dependent traits, we performed high-resolution genetic mapping25,33,38 of the change in growth upon chaperone inhibition. Based on over 1,000,000 growth measurements and a multivariate coarse- and fine-mapping procedure24, we identified 1,154 Hsp90-dependent loci throughout the genome that could be resolved to a single variant, exceeding the number previously identified by orders of magnitude [Supplementary File S1]. In total, 806 genes were implicated in at least one interaction between a variant and Hsp90 inhibition. Although Hsp90 generally influenced homozygotes more strongly, we also observed 567 cases in which the chaperone affected a variant’s dominance. Because most mutations originate as heterozygotes, this behavior, too, is likely an important facet of Hsp90’s influence on natural genetic variation. More broadly, considering the modest number of conditions we surveyed in our experiments, the involvement of more than 10% of genes in Hsp90-dependent phenotypes emphasizes the widespread influence of Hsp90 on heredity.

We next classified interactions into two broad categories: buffering interactions, in which the phenotypic effect of an allele was masked by Hsp90 and increased upon radicicol treatment (decanalization39 or the release of cryptic variation40); and potentiation interactions, in which the phenotypic effect of a variant was reduced when Hsp90 was inhibited (as with the transforming kinase v-Src17) [Fig. S1F]. Both types of interactions were common; buffering interactions were somewhat stronger than potentiations (median 15% larger; p < 10-4) [Fig. S1G]. In addition to buffering and potentiation, we noted that several Hsp90-dependent effects inverted a variant’s fitness. Although constituting a minority of the interactions we observed, the average effect size of such inversions was large [Fig. S1H] and may explain the ‘line-crossing’ Hsp90 dependence observed for randomly accumulated mutations11. Remarkably, Hsp90’s impact on individual variants was comparable to the phenotypic contributions of the variants themselves [Fig. S1I]; all these effects were large relative to the threshold for selection in this organism (s ∼ 10-5 - 10-4)41, suggesting that Hsp90 is poised to impact the evolutionary fate of a broad swath of natural genetic variation.

To confirm our statistical findings, we used genome editing to reconstruct the SNP in Avo342 linked to Hsp90-dependent rapamycin resistance [Fig. 1E]. Examining the AlphaFold model of this Hsp90 client29, we noted that the polymorphic Lys1342 residue lay in the Avo3 C-terminus, which protects Tor2 from rapamycin43, and is positioned to form a salt bridge likely disrupted by the Thr1342 substitution44 [Fig. 1F]. Consistent with this hypothesis, the alternate Thr1342 allele found in the RM11 vineyard isolate conferred a pronounced fitness defect in rapamycin that was attenuated by radicicol treatment, whereas the Lys1342 allele found in the clinical isolate conferred potentiated resistance [Fig. 1G]. Neither variant strongly influenced growth in the absence of rapamycin [Fig. S1J] and we obtained similar results with the chemically distinct Hsp90 inhibitor geldanamycin45, confirming that these phenotypes were transformed by Hsp90 activity.

To determine whether the effects of this variant were unique to these genetic backgrounds, we assessed the growth of 1,000 wild yeast isolates27 under rapamycin treatment with and without Hsp90 inhibition. More than 100 of the wild strains bore the alternate Thr1342 allele, and the Hsp90-dependent effect of the polymorphism was apparent across this panel despite the presence of variation at more than one million other loci [Fig. 1H]. These data establish that, despite genetic background effects, results from our focused cross could be translated species-wide.

sec.title: Hsp90 controls the phenotypic effects of regulatory variation
sec.p: Although the Avo3 variant altered protein sequence, closer inspection of our mapping data revealed that nearly half (542 of 1,154) of the fine-mapped variants were outside of annotated open reading frames. Indeed, regulatory variants accounted for more Hsp90-dependent heredity than protein-altering variants [Fig. 1I; Fig. S1K], even though only 30% of the yeast genome is noncoding. To better understand this surprising enrichment, we first investigated a T>C variant 206 base pairs upstream of the ERG11 transcription start site46 [Fig. 2A] linked to Hsp90-buffered resistance to the antifungal drugs tebuconazole and fluconazole, which inhibit Erg11 and are widely used in agriculture47 and the clinic48. Genomic reconstruction of the regulatory SNP recapitulated its buffered fitness effect [Fig. 2B; Fig. S2A]; the mutation had a negligible effect on growth in the absence of drug, regardless of Hsp90 activity [Fig. S2B]. These data establish that the buffered azole resistance was due to a regulatory variant rather than linked coding mutations.

We next examined the position of regulatory variants affected by Hsp90 relative to the transcriptional start sites (TSS) of the nearest genes. The largest and most frequent effects arose from variants immediately upstream of the TSS, consistent with altered transcription factor recruitment or transcription initiation. 123 Hsp90-dependent variants, however, were in the predicted 3’ UTR of mRNAs and 55 in the 5’ UTR [Fig. 2C], suggesting an important role for post-transcriptional regulation. Indeed, numerous Hsp90-dependent phenotypes arose from the 3’ UTR of the cysteine desulfurase gene NFS1, which exhibits nutrient-dependent RBP binding49. Introducing a G>A polymorphism 61 base pairs downstream of NFS1 into the YJM975 genetic background conferred pronounced buffered sensitivity to fluconazole and concomitant buffered resistance to the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin, confirming the role of this 3’ UTR in chaperone-dependent heredity [Fig. 2D]. Interestingly, we previously implicated coding variation at NFS1 in buffered rapamycin resistance21, suggesting that Hsp90-dependence may be a general property of variation at this gene. More broadly, our data demonstrate that the fitness effects of cis-regulatory variation alone can be potently controlled by the Hsp90 foldase.

sec.title: Allelic imbalance is invariant to Hsp90 activity
sec.p: To better understand the molecular origins of the phenotypic interactions between Hsp90 and natural regulatory variants, we performed allele-specific mRNA sequencing of the heterozygous diploid parent of our genetic mapping panel. This approach capitalizes on polymorphisms in transcribed regions that ‘tag’ transcripts as originating from either the RM11 or YJM975 parental chromosomes [Fig. S2C]; a predominance of one haplotype over the other indicates the presence of a cis-acting regulatory variant at that gene50. Of the 451 phenotypic interactions between non-coding variants and Hsp90 in our mapping experiments, 107 (26%) exhibited significant allele-specific expression (ASE) under radicicol treatment (Bonferroni-corrected q < 0.05; see Methods, Fig. S2D, and Supplementary File S2 for details and power calculations). We first hypothesized that Hsp90 inhibition might alter effects of these interacting SNPs on mRNA levels, causing their phenotypic effects to change. Yet to our surprise, allelic ratios were largely unchanged by Hsp90 inhibition across all segregating polymorphisms, whether or not their phenotypic effects depended on the chaperone [Fig. 2E; Fig. S2E]. The buffered variant at ERG11, for instance, showed pronounced RM11-biased expression (mean RM:YJM allelic ratio = 1.78), consistent with our observation that the RM11 allele conferred azole resistance [Fig. 2F], but this ratio was unchanged when Hsp90 was inhibited.

We did note, however, that the overall level of ERG11 expression was markedly decreased by radicicol treatment. This observation led us to hypothesize that Hsp90 might control allele-specific fitness consequences without impacting the mRNA allelic ratio simply by altering the amount of folded, active protein in trans. Such a model would predict that Hsp90 would have a larger phenotypic effect on variants with greater allelic imbalance. Indeed, despite having little effect on mRNA ASE itself, Hsp90 more strongly impacted the consequences of variants with significant allelic imbalances (p < 0.01) [Fig. S2F]. Moreover, if most proteins are present at levels that do not limit growth under most conditions51, then we might expect such interactions to be predominantly buffered; buffering interactions were stronger than potentiations for variants associated with mRNA cis-regulation (p < 0.03) [Fig. 2G; Fig. S2G]. Studies in diverse organisms have illustrated the potential for Hsp90 to have profound and lineage-specific consequences for development16, often resulting in the release of cryptic phenotypic variation. Our results suggest that these interactions could arise from the confluence of cis-acting variants with trans effects that depend on Hsp90 activity.

sec.title: Hsp90 modifies variation in direct clients and their targets
sec.p: Our observation that coding and non-coding variants drove Hsp90-dependent phenotypes led us to ask whether either were linked directly to Hsp90’s well-characterized chaperone activity or instead were connected by effects that percolated through the protein-protein interaction network. Strikingly, modified alleles were much more like to occur in genes encoding Hsp90 clients29 (p < 0.0007 for both Hsp82 and Hsc82) [Fig. 3A]9. Because multiple chaperones are often involved in folding, we also searched the clientele of the Hsp70 family of chaperones, which collaborate with Hsp9052,53; these clients were also enriched for modified alleles (p < 10-6 for Ssa1/2; p < 0.01 for Ssa4) [Fig. 3A]. Notably, although the Hsp90-dependent phenotypes we identified were mechanistically diverse and often driven by cis-regulatory variation, protein-folding activity directly connected Hsp90 and Hsp70 to the majority (59.8%) of interacting variants.

To investigate percolating effects [Fig. 3B], we examined the targets of three classes of regulatory proteins that are prominent amongst Hsp90’s clientele: kinases, transcription factors (TFs), and E3 ubiquitin ligases. We first assessed which kinases might connect Hsp90 inhibition to changes in the effects of natural variants, identifying eighteen kinases whose targets31 were enriched for Hsp90-dependent variation (Bonferroni-corrected q value < 0.05) [Fig. 3C, Fig. S3A]. Twelve interact with Hsc82 or Hsp8254, indicating a potential mechanism for the modification of variants in their clients. Ninety-two predicted targets of the client MAP kinase Slt2, for example, bore interacting alleles55. The targets of the eighteen enriched kinases accounted for another 32.2% of the interacting alleles in our experiments. Thus, a total of 92.0% of Hsp90-dependent variants were connected directly via chaperone activity or via kinases, a deeply conserved class of Hsp90 client proteins.

We next asked whether Hsp90’s phenotypic effects might likewise percolate through TFs and ubiquitin E3 ligases. Modified variants were enriched at the targets of five TFs [Fig. 3C; see Methods]32 but not amongst the physical interactors of E3 ligases54 [see Methods], perhaps because the substrate specificity of E3 ligases remains poorly characterized56. These results suggest that, first, although the influence of Hsp90 on the genotype-to-phenotype map is complex, it is interpretable based on our knowledge of the functional roles of Hsp90, its close collaborator Hsp70, and key categories of client proteins. Second, the position of Hsp90 as a hub of hubs facilitates the simultaneous modification of alleles throughout a complex regulon attributable to both direct and second-order interactions. Indeed, multiple mechanisms may converge on a single protein: many interacting alleles at direct clients were also trans targets of client regulators. Finally, the effects of Hsp90 are similarly likely to reach both regulatory and coding variation at the members of this diverse regulon.

sec.title: The influence of Hsp90 on complex heredity
sec.p: Our mapping approach provided a comprehensive picture of Hsp90-dependent heredity, revealing that up to 90.0% of Hsp90’s effect on fitness was due to changes in the phenotypic effects of genetic variants (median of 55.7% across all traits) [Fig. S4A]. Consistent with the widespread reservoir of co-regulated variants under the influence of Hsp90 activity, the Hsp90-dependence of phenotype was often genetically complex—the median trait comprised 142 modified alleles [Fig. S4B]. Hsp90-dependent growth in maltose, for example, depended on three separate large-effect alleles segregating at the MAL1, MAL3, and GAL10 loci. The modified loci at MAL3 and GAL10 included regulatory variants, but a large-effect buffered locus at MAL1 was due to a deletion encompassing three maltose metabolic genes: IMA1, MAL11, and MAL1357. The segmental deletion was much more deleterious to growth in maltose when Hsp90 was inhibited [Fig. S4C].

These joint interactions resulted in a remarkably environment-specific effect of Hsp90 inhibition on fitness [Fig. S4D]; despite Hsp90’s pronounced impact in maltose, the three loci had negligible Hsp90 dependence in raffinose [Fig. S4E]. This was a general property of Hsp90-dependent heredity in our experiments: the effect of Hsp90 inhibition on the phenotypic consequences of variation was uncorrelated between different stress conditions [Fig. S4F]. To better understand how Hsp90 influenced the concerted effects of multiple variants, we examined how chaperone inhibition impacted the fitness of the eight possible combinations of homozygous genotypes at these three loci. The three simultaneous interactions altered the connectivity of the phenotypic landscape in maltose: several mutational steps were permitted (did not significantly decrease fitness) exclusively when Hsp90 was either fully active or inhibited [Fig. 4A]. This in turn altered the mutational paths accessible between genotypes without a stepwise decrease in fitness [Fig. 4B]. Simultaneously, Hsp90 inhibition coarsened the landscape: the effect of single-mutation steps in this mutational neighborhood was increased when Hsp90 was inhibited in maltose, in contrast to the same mutational neighborhood in raffinose [Fig. 4C]. The same was true under fluconazole treatment, in which variants at ERG11, PDR1, and GRE2 were buffered [Fig. 4D]. These results illustrate how Hsp90 inhibition under stress can affect polygenic adaptation when the effects of multiple segregating polymorphisms are altered. By opening or foreclosing paths in the mutational space, chaperone activity shapes the tradeoff between metabolic specialization and the accessibility of other phenotypes when the environment changes.

The identification of interacting variants not only at the MAL but also the FLO genes, young, rapidly evolving subtelomeric gene families with highly variable gene content across S. cerevisiae58 [Supplementary File S1], prompted us to ask if evolutionarily young genes, as a group, were predisposed to harbor Hsp90-dependent variation. After stratifying all S. cerevisiae genes by evolutionary age59 [Fig. 4E], we found that the youngest genes harbored alleles that exhibited the strongest Hsp90-dependent phenotypic effects [Fig. 4F]. Moreover, this enrichment was driven predominantly by regulatory variation [Fig. 4G] and strong buffering interactions [Fig. S4G]. Thus, Hsp90-buffered variation provides a potent reservoir of phenotypic novelty, particularly at genes that contribute to niche-specific adaptation and harbor more condition-specific alleles of large effect58.

sec.title: A general model for buffering by Hsp90
sec.p: How does Hsp90 simultaneously drive such diverse effects and affect the outcomes of coding and non-coding variation alike? We returned to two observations from genetic mapping: first, that Hsp70 and Hsp90’s direct clients were enriched in interacting genes, and second, that regulatory variation, which does not alter protein sequence, was a driver of Hsp90-dependent heredity. These observations led us to hypothesize that Hsp90-dependence was often an intrinsic property of certain gene products, rather than a property of mutations that led one allele to become Hsp90-dependent.

To directly test this idea, we again revisited the buffered ERG11 regulatory variant. Interestingly, genetic mapping also suggested a role for the neighboring Erg11Asn433Lys coding variant in azole resistance when Hsp90 was fully active. We hypothesized that due to a reduction in Erg11 activity upon Hsp90 inhibition, the effects of both variants would be buffered [Fig. S5A]. After constructing strains bearing each variant singly as well as a strain bearing both mutations, we found that, strikingly, the single and double mutants all exhibited buffered resistance to azoles (p < 10-4; p < 0.001) [Fig. S5BC]. Thus, disparate mutations at the ERG11 locus were similarly labile to Hsp90 perturbation. Moreover, cryptic phenotypes may be attributable to compound alleles at loci that are sensitive to Hsp90 activity.

We next sought to explain why the effects of these mutations were suppressed by Hsp90. Building on the observation that cis-regulatory variation was frequently buffered, we hypothesized that a nonlinear activity-to-fitness relationship could be responsible [Fig. 5A]. If many copies of a protein are improperly folded or aberrantly post-translationally modified, or if total expression is decreased, a cis-regulatory variant of constant molecular consequence will exhibit an increased fitness impact due to the increased local slope of the activity-fitness sigmoid. This sigmoidal relationship exists for combinations of mutations in proteins60,62 and for combinations of cis-regulatory variants at different genes61, and has two implications: the fitness effects of arbitrary perturbations to Erg11 activity should depend on Hsp90 activity, and reducing Erg11 activity should be buffered.

To test these predictions quantitatively, we used synthetic CRISPR interference63 to reduce ERG11 transcription in the YJM975 parent [Fig. 5B]. As compared to a non-targeting guide RNA, reducing ERG11 transcription caused a dose-dependent sensitivity to fluconazole [Fig. 5C]. In turn, Hsp90 inhibition caused a progressively greater sensitivity concomitant with decreasing ERG11 transcription (p < 10-8) [Fig. 5CD]; that is, the phenotypic consequences of losing Erg11 activity were systematically buffered by Hsp90, just as we observed for natural variation. Reducing ERG11 levels had no effect in the absence of azole, regardless of Hsp90 activity [Fig. S5D], and comparable results were obtained in the RM11 parent, indicating that the phenomenon was independent of the ERG11 genotype [Fig. S5E].

Finally, we asked whether we could identify genes with a steep activity-fitness relationship that might be more prone to Hsp90-dependent buffering. We examined haploinsufficient genes— those whose heterozygous mutants affect the diploid—because reducing their expression by approximately one-half leads to an appreciable phenotype [Fig. S5F]. Indeed, mutations in these genes64 had stronger Hsp90-dependent effects [Fig. S5G]. This did not arise simply because many haploinsufficient genes are also essential: essential genes that are not haploinsufficient did not exhibit this trend. Moreover, in concordance with our model, these enrichments arose exclusively amongst buffering interactions [Fig. 5E]. Intriguingly, human genes scored as more essential (based on the frequency of predicted loss-of-function mutants in gnomAD65) and human genes found to be haploinsufficient in embryonic stem cells66 are also enriched for known Hsp90 interactors67 [Fig. 5F]. These genes may likewise be candidates to harbor Hsp90-buffered genetic variation arising from a sigmoidal activity-fitness relationship.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The influence of Hsp90 on the developmental and adaptive consequences of genetic variation has long been appreciated. However, aside from a handful of examples of mutations in client proteins, the molecular underpinnings of these effects have remained enigmatic. Here, our nucleotide-resolution approach revealed a surprise: cis-regulatory variants, which by definition do not alter protein stability, emerged as a driver of nearly half of Hsp90-dependent phenotypes. This behavior arose naturally from the chaperone’s pervasive influence on activity-fitness relationships via direct clients and core regulatory proteins. Buffering interactions, which are enriched amongst these relationships, position Hsp90 to govern the release of cryptic, potentially adaptive variation in this regulatory circuitry. This mechanism combines the evolutionary advantages of cis-regulatory variation, which enables sophisticated spatiotemporal programming, with exquisite stress-dependent regulation of the Hsp90 chaperone machinery to release adaptive phenotypes under stress.

The preponderance of this behavior in the concise budding yeast genome suggests that interactions between Hsp90 and regulatory variation may be even more prominent in organisms with more elaborate regulatory architectures. Indeed, the pragmatic need for a low density of polymorphisms in our panel means that our results likely represent a lower bound on the prevalence of this phenomenon, even in yeast. Significant technical advances are still needed to understand Hsp90-dependent alleles of small effect and Hsp90-dependent genetic epistasis, both of which may play a role in Hsp90-dependent heredity. Nonetheless, even generous estimates of the contribution of epistasis suggest that, for some phenotypic transformations driven by the chaperone, other heritable variation that depends on Hsp90 activity (e.g. prions68 or long-lived chromatin modifications5) may play an important role.

Our experiments identified numerous instances in which the impact of Hsp90 activity on fixed natural polymorphisms was as large as the effect of the variant alone. These were widespread throughout the genome, and although it is not straightforward to directly infer s from genetic mapping experiments, the effects we observed likely exceed the threshold for effective selection by multiple orders of magnitude. That many Hsp90-contingent effects were buffered and highly condition-specific further suggests a role in adaptation, particularly in rapidly changing environments. The environmental specificity of these interactions means that buffered variation can accumulate under normal conditions without compromising fitness. At the same time, this variation is shaped by repeated selection that is only engaged when Hsp90 activity is compromised. This allows a greater diversity of genetic variation to persist in the population, broadening the accessible adaptive trajectories under stress. Moreover, by virtue of repeated cycles of selection, this reservoir of genetic potential may be predisposed to drive adaptive phenotypes.

Our results may also explain why Hsp90 inhibition has profound consequences for development, as the revelation of phenotypes due to cis-acting regulation are likely to have especially potent consequences in this context. Moreover, our observation that such variants were enriched in direct clients of Hsp90 and Hsp70, as well as their targets, suggests that these classes of proteins will be fertile ground to identify such interactions. Indeed, our data indicate that cis-regulatory variants controlling proteins already well-known to interact with Hsp90 may be especially profitable to explore.

Understanding how environmental change shapes Hsp90’s clientele and the regulatory circuitry under its control is an intriguing area for future study. Nonetheless, our results suggest multiple potential advantages to an Hsp90-dependent activity-fitness relationship that incorporates regimes with varying slopes. This relationship buffers modest perturbations to activity but enhances the phenotypic consequences of large excursions; indeed, haploinsufficient genes may preferentially harbor buffered cis-regulatory effects. Our approach opens a path to ask whether other cellular components that are ‘hubs of hubs’ might also play important roles in the expression of genetic variation4 and to characterize the spectrum of natural variants controlled by these factors.

Prior studies have indicated that Hsp90 facilitates the accumulation of coding variation in clients69, accelerating their evolution70. Our findings suggest that the chaperone enables the accumulation of cryptic regulatory variation at these genes at least as strongly, providing an unappreciated and appealing potential mechanism for the influence of Hsp90 on developmental evolution in diverse systems from fruit flies to Mexican cavefish. Likewise, in cancer and in pathogens, the buffering of drug-resistant regulatory mutations by Hsp90 may allow their accumulation, subsequently being enriched amongst the surviving cells following treatment and promoting future drug-resistance. This, in turn, suggests that a paradigm that favors therapeutic Hsp90 inhibition, predicated on the Hsp90-addicted v-Src kinase, may be counterproductive if cryptic, buffered resistance is revealed and enriched. Distinguishing cases in which Hsp90 inhibition is helpful or deleterious to treatment is an important question for future investigation, as is the relationship of an individual’s reservoir of Hsp90-dependent buffering capacity with their polygenic risk for genetic disease. The decline of this buffering reservoir throughout lifespan may contribute to the emergence of pathologies with age.

Our findings address long-standing mechanistic questions surrounding the role of Hsp90 in transmuting genetic variation into selectable phenotypes. Hsp90’s activity and connectivity with an expansive regulon of client proteins position it to control activity-fitness relationships throughout the core eukaryotic regulatory circuitry. In turn, the effects of numerous coding and regulatory variants simultaneously depend strongly on its stress-regulated activity. Finally, the acute environmental specificity of these buffered fitness effects facilitates their accumulation in advance of stress. Together, these features render Hsp90 a central governor of the critical evolutionary tradeoff between robustness and adaptability in the face of a changing environment, when diversification is most crucial.

sec.title: Yeast strains
sec.p: The construction and genotypes of the parents of the F6 haploid collection, RM11 and YJM975, are described in She and Jarosz25. Briefly, the F6 diploids used here were constructed by mating leu-HYGR and LEU+hygS F6 haploid isolates genotyped previously25 on YPD agar [RPI] followed by selection for diploidy on synthetic defined medium lacking leucine [Sunrise] and supplemented with 200 mg/L hygromycin. These F6 diploids were arrayed into 384-well microtiter plates for cryostorage in SD-Leu+Hyg with 15% glycerol. All robotic manipulations were carried out using a Singer ROTOR pinning robot. The RM11 and YJM975 haploid parents of the original genetic cross bear auxotrophies used to facilitate crossing that are not present in the final F6 diploid mapping panel. To avoid undesired interactions with these auxotrophies during validation experiments, reconstructions of Hsp90-interacting alleles were carried out in strains YDJ6635 (YJM975a from the SGRP haploid collection26) and YDJ6649 (a spore derived from diploid RM11a/α), both of which are auxotrophic only for uracil. Key yeast strains and plasmids are listed in Supplementary Table S2.

sec.title: v-Src assay for Hsp90 activity
sec.p: v-Src was expressed under the control of a galactose-inducible promoter from PDJ308 in the F0 heterozygous diploid YDJ5924. Cells were grown on solid medium containing either 2% glucose (repressing) or 2% galactose (inducing) as the sole carbon source and with or without 10 μM radicicol; Images were cropped using custom R scripts and spot sizes were quantified using the gitter R package71.

sec.title: Western blotting
sec.p: Cell lysis was conducted by bead beating in 20% trichloroacetic acid for 10 min at 50 Hz. Cell mass was normalized by optical density prior to lysis; approximately 1 OD-mL of cell mass was used per sample. Protein was precipitated for 30 min at ∼23,000 x g at 4°C and the precipitate was resuspended in Tris pH 7.5 with 2% SDS before denaturation at 95°C for 5 min. Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis was performed using 12-20% gradient gels at 120 V for 75 min. Proteins were transferred to PVDF membranes in Towbin transfer buffer for 2 hr at 100 V. Membranes were blocked with rehydrated milk, probed overnight at 4°C, and developed using WestFemto chemiluminescent substrate. Matched gels loaded with equal sample volumes were stained with Coomassie brilliant blue in parallel to western blotting. When required for reprobing, membranes were stripped of primary and secondary antibodies by boiling in Tris-buffered saline for 5 min. Antibodies are listed in Supplementary Table S4.

sec.title: Yeast culture conditions
sec.p: Unless otherwise noted, yeast were propagated and phenotyped in minimal glucose medium consisting of 6.7 g/L yeast nitrogen base [RPI] and 20 g/L glucose [Sigma] supplemented with 20 mg/L uracil [Sigma] to satisfy the lone auxotrophy of the F6 diploid panel. Prior to phenotyping experiments, diploid strains were revived from frozen stocks in liquid SD-Leu+Hyg medium in 384-well microtiter plates, propagated 24 hr at 30°C, then pinned to 1536-spot arrays on minimal glucose agar PlusPlates [Singer] and grown for 24 hr – 48 hr at 30°C. 1536-spot source plates prepared as described above were replicated to conditions as indicated using a Singer ROTOR pinning robot. Plates were incubated at 30°C and imaged at 24 hr intervals using an Epson V800 scanner. Images were cropped using custom R scripts and spot sizes were quantified using the gitter R package. Colony sizes were extracted for genetic mapping using custom MATLAB scripts. Working concentrations for the various environmental perturbations are described in Supplementary Table S1.

sec.title: Genetic mapping
sec.p: Prior to analysis, colony sizes were normalized to mean 0 and variance 1 (i.e. Z-scored) and filtered for outliers attributable to missing spots or debris (due to occasional pinning errors or image artifacts). Trait vectors were filtered for strains with an excess of missing genotypes and markers with insufficient genotype coverage were excluded. Statistical genetic mapping was performed essentially as described previously24, with the difference that in the present work we mapped the change in the Z-scored trait for each segregant in each condition with and without 10 μM radicicol treatment. Briefly, coarse mapping was conducted by sequential stepwise selection on the homozygous followed by full (homozygous and heterozygous) genotype matrices. Fine mapping was conducted by ANOVA on in silico allele swaps as described in She and Jarosz 201825. The genotype matrix included geometric pseudogenotypes corresponding to edge wells and to capture systematic plate-to-plate variability. Loci that were fine-mapped for one trait were inferred to be the underlying causal variant for other traits in which they were the lead candidate. All trait and genotype data and the custom code used for mapping are available at https://github.com/cjakobson/mapping/tree/master/hsp90mapping and https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/aakdomnjk4rk949kvpsnw/h?rlkey=2vdos9m8dm3ybmkwcxm2ct8o6&dl=0 and summarized in Supplementary File S1.

sec.title: Genome editing using CRISPEY
sec.p: Oligonucleotides containing appropriate guide and donor sequences for CRISPEY editing were designed as described by Sharon and colleagues28 using code provided in that study. Oligos were designed separately for RM11 to YJM975 and YJM975 to RM11 mutations to account for differences in guide and template sequences due to neighboring polymorphisms (Supplementary Table S3). SRR800790 and SRR1569760 were used as reference genomes for YJM975 and RM11, respectively. Gene editing was conducted largely as described in Sharon and colleagues28. Briefly, dsDNA was synthesized from oligos by PCR, dsDNA fragments were inserted into the NotI-digested PDJ2318 editing plasmid by isothermal assembly using a 2xHiFi Assembly kit, and the ligated DNA was transformed into chemically competent E. coli. Gene editing of yeast was performed by transformation of the editing plasmid and selection on SD-Ura followed by 24h of growth in synthetic galactose medium lacking uracil. From these editing reactions, yeast cells were streaked to single colonies on YPD plates followed by restreaking to 5-FOA plates to cure the editing plasmid. Single colonies were genotyped by PCR and Sanger sequencing of the desired edited locus; screening two colonies per edit was typically sufficient to recover an edited clone.

sec.title: Genomes yeast strains and phylogenetic analysis
sec.p: Genotype information for the 1,002 Genomes collection and the corresponding yeast strains27 were a generous gift of Joseph Schacherer (Univ. of Strasbourg). Frozen stocks were revived and phenotyping experiments performed as described above for the F6 diploid mapping panel. Growth measurements and quantification were conducted by optical scanning of Singer PlusPlates using gitter and custom code as described above.

sec.title: Allele-specific expression analysis
sec.p: Cells were grown in triplicate in minimal media as described above with and without 10 μM radicicol and harvested at OD ∼ 0.8-1.0. Cell pellets were snap-frozen and stored at -80°C before submission to BGI (www.bgi.com/us/home) for RNA extraction, polyA enrichment, reverse transcription, and sequencing. Transcript abundance was estimated using kallisto72 and read counts per-site were estimated with bcftools73 from kallisto pseudo-alignments. Allele-specific expression was called per-site based on a binomial test against the prior of major allele frequency = 0.5, with genome-wide Bonferroni correction based on the number of transcribed biallelic sites. Indels were excluded. After per-site calling, SNPs were assigned to genes and genes were assigned allelic imbalances if any SNP associated with their transcript exhibited significant allele-specific expression in any of the three replicate sequencing samples. Allelic imbalances agreed well between replicates [Fig. S6]. Results are summarized in Supplementary File S2. Sensitivity estimates were conducted based on a sliding simulated read depth followed by binomial tests, with mock Bonferroni correction performed assuming the true number of transcribed biallelic sites in the hybrid diploid.

sec.title: Homozygous diploid mRNA sequencing
sec.p: Cell were grown in triplicate in minimal media as described above with and without 10 μM radicicol and harvested at OD ∼ 0.8-1.0. Cell pellets were snap-frozen and stored at -80°C before submission to BGI for RNA extraction, polyA enrichment, reverse transcription, and sequencing, as described above for allele-specific expression analysis. Transcript abundance was again estimated using kallisto. Transcripts per million (TPM) estimates agreed well between replicates [Fig. S7]. Results are summarized in Supplementary File S3.

sec.title: CRISPR interference
sec.p: CRISPRi plasmids were cloned as described in Smith et al. Briefly, the anti-ERG11 guide RNA sequence was ordered as an ssDNA oligonucleotide and amplified using extension primers as described in63. The CRISPRi plasmid (p416gT-Gal4-dCas9-Mxi1) was opened with NotI and the anti-ERG11 guide inserted by isothermal assembly using a 2xHiFi Assembly kit, and the ligated DNA was transformed into chemically competent E. coli to create PDJ2494. After transformation into S. cerevisiae alongside a matched control plasmid with a non-targeting gRNA (PDJ397), strains were pre-grown for 24 hrs in the appropriate concentration of anhydrotetracycline (aTc) to establish steady-state knock-down then subjected to phenotyping under the appropriate aTc concentrations as described.

sec.title: Bioinformatic resources and enrichment analyses
sec.p: Genomic analyses used the S. cerevisiae R64 reference genome unless otherwise noted. Transcription start and end sites were retrieved from74. Targets of sequence-specific transcription factors were retrieved from32. Predicted kinase targets were retrieved from31. Enriched TF hits were logically connected to Hsp90 function: Mig175 and Pdr120 interact with Hsp90; Hsp90 inhibition downregulates Met4 targets6; and Yap176 and Stb577 homologues interact with Hsp90 in other species. Modified alleles at targets of Pdr1 and Stb5 were enriched for fitness effects in fluconazole, consistent with the role of these TFs in multidrug resistance. Although two E3 ligases (Rsp5 and Mpe1) exhibited modest enrichments, none were significant (q < 0.05) after multiple-testing correction. Gene and protein descriptions and GO terms were retrieved from SGD54 and UniProt78. Predicted protein structures were retrieved from the AlphaFold Protein Structure Database44. Gene age estimates were retrieved from59. Haploinsufficient genes in S. cerevisiae were retrieved from64. pLoF data was retrieved from65. Haploinsufficient genes in human embryonic stem cells were retrieved from66.

sec.title: Strain and plasmid availability
sec.p: The original F6 haploid genetic mapping panel is available from the National Collection of Yeast Cultures and the F6 diploid mapping panel and all other yeast strains described here are available upon request to Prof. Daniel F. Jarosz (jarosz@stanford.edu). Bacterial strains bearing plasmids used here are likewise available upon request. Various CRISPEY gene editing plasmids are available from AddGene.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank Joseph Schacherer for the 1,002 Yeast Genomes Project strain collection, Justin Smith for the CRISPR interference plasmid, and the Jarosz Lab for critical feedback and advice. This work was supported by the NIH (DP2-GM119140, RF1-AG057334, R01-AG06341801, and R01-HG012366 to D.F.J.; F32-GM125162 to C.M.J.), the National Science Foundation (NSF-MCB116762 to D.F.J.), the Swiss National Science Foundation (P2ZHP3_174735 to J.A.-R.), the European Molecular Biology Organization (ALTF 724-2018 to J.A.-R.), a Searle Scholar Award (14-SSP-210 to D.F.J.), a Kimmel Scholar Award (SKF-15-154 to D.F.J.), a Vallee Scholar Award (to D.F.J.) and a Discovery Innovation Award from Stanford University (to D.F.J.). D.F.J. is also a Science and Engineering Fellow of the David and Lucile Packard Foundation. Some of the computing for this project was performed on the Sherlock cluster. We would like to thank Stanford University and the Stanford Research Computing Center for providing computational resources and support that contributed to these research results.

sec.title: Data and code availability
sec.p: All data supporting the findings of this study are available within the paper and its Supplementary Information. All trait and genotype data required to recapitulate the mapping results are available at https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/aakdomnjk4rk949kvpsnw/h?rlkey=2vdos9m8dm3ybmkwcxm2ct8o6&dl=0. All custom genetic mapping code is available at https://github.com/cjakobson/mapping/tree/master/hsp90mapping. RNA sequencing data are available at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GSE242925). Raw images of phenotyping experiments, custom code for cropping images and estimating spot sizes, and code for bioinformatic analyses and generating figures are available upon reasonable request to Prof. Daniel F. Jarosz (jarosz@stanford.edu).

fn.p: C.M.J., J.A.-R., and D.F.J. conceived the project. C.M.J. performed pilot, mapping, genome editing, phenotyping, and transcriptomic experiments, designed and implemented the genetic mapping pipeline, performed transcriptomic and bioinformatic analyses, and prepared the figures. J.A.-R. performed pilot experiments, designed genome editing reagents, and performed genome editing experiments. C.M.J. wrote the original draft of the manuscript. C.M.J. and D.F.J. reviewed and edited the manuscript with input from J.A.-R.

caption.title: Identifying individual mutations underlying Hsp90-dependent phenotypes.
caption.p: (A) Schematic of genetic mapping population and hypothetical Hsp90-dependent phenotypes of different strains. (B) Normalized growth of randomly selected representative progeny in rapamycin with Hsp90 active (grey) and inhibited with radicicol (red), sorted by growth with Hsp90 active. Shown are n = 146 randomly selected progeny. (C) Manhattan plot of univariate genetic mapping of Hsp90-dependent rapamycin resistance. Loci are in genomic order, with chromosomes as indicated. A strong association at the AVO3/RICTOR locus is highlighted. LOD, log of the odds distribution. (D) Growth in rapamycin with Hsp90 active (no shading) and inhibited with radicicol (red shading) of strains bearing the sensitive (blue) and resistant (orange) alleles of Avo3/RICTOR. Data shown are mean and s.e.m.; number of progeny with each homozygous genotype is as indicated; F test p value from multivariate regression; n as indicated. (E) Univariate genetic mapping of Hsp90-dependent rapamycin resistance (LOD score; left ordinate) overlaid with multivariate fine-mapping (ANOVA QTN score; right ordinate) of the same phenotype, highlighting the causal variant Avo3Thr1342Lys. (F) Alphafold2 predicted structure of Avo3, highlighting the causal residue Avo3Lys1342 and its proximity to Avo3Glu1362. (G) Growth in rapamycin of genome-edited strains with Hsp90 active (no shading) and inhibited (red shading). The left panel shows wild type YJM975 Avo3Lys1342 and edited YJM975 Avo3Thr1342 strains (blue stars); the right panel shows wild type RM11 Avo3Thr1342 strains and edited RM11 Avo3Lys1342 strains (orange stars). Hsp90 was inhibited with radicicol (rad) and geldanamycin A (GdA). Data shown are mean and s.e.m. normalized to the wild type; p values by two-sample t test; n = 96 per genotype. (H) Replication of the Hsp90-dependent phenotype in wild isolates sorted by their Avo3 genotype as indicated: Avo3Thr1342 in blue (n = 152) and Avo3Lys1342 in orange (n = 806). Growth was measured with Hsp90 active (no shading) and inhibited (red shading) Data shown are mean and s.e.m. normalized to the growth of the RM11 Avo3Thr1342 allele; p value by two-sample t test relative to growth without radicicol. (I) Cumulative frequency plots of multivariate regression p values for protein altering (dark blue), synonymous (light blue), and regulatory (pink) Hsp90-modified variants.

caption.title: Hsp90 controls the phenotypic outcomes of cis-regulatory variation.
caption.p: (A) Univariate genetic mapping of Hsp90-dependent fluconazole resistance (LOD score; left ordinate) overlaid with multivariate fine-mapping (ANOVA QTN score; right ordinate) of the same phenotype, highlighting the causal variant ERG11122014C>T. Indicated are a SNP in the ERG11 ORF (blue shading) and SNPs in the associate regulatory region (grey shading) (B) Growth in fluconazole of genome-edited strains with Hsp90 active (no shading) and inhibited with radicicol (+Hsp90i; red shading). Each panel shows wild type YJM975 ERG11122014T, edited YJM975 ERG11122014C (blue stars), wild type RM11 ERG11122014C, and edited RM11 ERG11122014T (orange stars) strains. Data shown are mean and s.e.m. normalized to the wild type; p values by two-sample t test against the same mutant strain without radicicol treatment; n = 384 per genotype. (C) Frequency of Hsp90-modified regulatory variants occurring, respectively, upstream of the TSS, downstream of the TSS (5’ UTR), upstream of the TES (3’ UTR), and downstream of the TES for the nearest gene(s). (D) Growth in fluconazole (left) and doxorubicin (right) of genome-edited strains with Hsp90 active (no shading) and inhibited with radicicol (+Hsp90i; red shading). Each panel shows wild type YJM975 NFS1*61G, and edited YJM975 NFS1*61A (blue stars) strains. Data shown are mean and s.e.m. normalized to the wild type; p values by two-sample t test against the same mutant strain without radicicol treatment; n = 384 per genotype. (E) Allelic ratio (RM counts/YJM975 counts) in the hybrid diploid with Hsp90 inhibited by radicicol (abscissa) or with Hsp90 active (ordinate) for all SNPs with genome-wide significant allele-specific expression (grey) and for SNPs with Hsp90-dependent phenotypic effects (red). Data shown are mean allelic ratios across three replicates for each condition. (F) Top: Schematic of ERG11 alleles in the hybrid diploid; indicated are the Hsp90-dependent 122014C>T regulatory variant and the Erg11Lys433Asn tag SNP. Below left: estimated counts at Erg11Lys433Asn tag SNP for the RM11 allele (blue) and the YJM975 allele (orange) with Hsp90 inhibited with radicicol (red shading) or Hsp90 active. Bars show mean and dots show replicates. Below right: Mean allelic ratio (RM11 counts/YM975 counts) at the Erg11Lys433Asn tag SNP with Hsp90 inhibited with radicicol (red) or Hsp90 active (grey). Bars show mean and dots show replicates; p values by binomial test; N = 3. (G) Absolute change in allele effect for Hsp90-modified regulatory variants that were buffered (green) and potentiated (purple), sorted by whether the transcript exhibited allele-specific expression (left) or had a tag SNP but no allele-specific expression (right). Box plots show the median and upper and lower quartiles; whiskers show 1.5 times the interquartile range; p values by two-sample t test; n as indicated.

caption.title: Hsp90-dependent phenotypes arise from chaperone clients and the targets of client regulatory proteins.
caption.p: (A) Fraction of genes bearing Hsp90-modified alleles (blue) and all other genes (grey) that are clients of the indicated chaperones. p values by Fisher’s exact test. (B) Schematic of direct and indirect interactions between the Hsp90/70 chaperone network and mutated gene products. (C) Odds ratio that Hsp90-modified variants lie amongst the targets of the indicated kinases (left) and lie amongst the targets of the indicated sequence-specific TFs (right; grey) relative to all other segregating variants. p values by Fisher’s exact test; shown are kinases and TFs with Bonferroni-corrected q < 0.05.

caption.title: Complex genetic architectures of Hsp90-dependent heredity.
caption.p: (A) Phenotypic landscape of growth in maltose (left) or maltose with radicicol (right). Genotypes at MAL1, MAL3, and GAL10 are as indicated; the fitness of each genotype is encoded in the line width of the enclosing circle. Grey arrows indicate permissible mutations that do not significantly decrease fitness (nominal p > 0.05) in either condition; black arrows show mutations only permissible in maltose; red arrows show mutations only permissible in maltose with radicicol. (B) Phenotypic landscapes with genotypes as in (A) simplified to highlight mutational paths accessible by drift (solid lines; reversible) and paths that alter fitness (dashed lines; irreversible). (C) Change in mean normalized growth on maltose for all possible single-mutation steps amongst GAL10, MAL1, and MAL3 alleles without (black) and with (red; +Hsp90i) inhibition of Hsp90 by radicicol. Box plots show the median and upper and lower quartiles; whiskers show 1.5 times the interquartile range. (D) As in (C), but for ERG11, PDR1, and GRE2 in fluconazole and glucose. (E) Schematic of phylogeny used to classify S. cerevisiae genes by their evolutionary age based on the presence or absence of homologues in the taxa shown. (F) Absolute change in allele effect for Hsp90-modified variants with ages as indicated. Box plots show the median and upper and lower quartiles; whiskers show 1.5 times the interquartile range; p value by two-sample t test of the indicated age group against all other variants. n as indicated. (G) As in (F), but only for Hsp90-modified variants outside of open reading frames.

caption.title: Hsp90 modifies the activity-fitness relationship.
caption.p: (A) Schematic of the effect of Hsp90 inhibition on fitness assuming a non-linear relationship between protein activity and phenotype. Increasing CRISPRi expression reduces ERG11 expression; the fitness consequences of these changes are amplified when total activity is compromised by Hsp90 inhibition. (B) Schematic of CRISPR transcriptional interference mediated by a dCas9:Mxi1 fusion and anhydrotetracycline (+aTc) inducible gRNA. (C) Growth of YJM975 haploid strains expressing either a non-targeting control gRNA (open boxes) or an anti-ERG11 gRNA (closed boxes) in fluconazole without the addition of radicicol (grey boxes) or with radicicol (red boxes). Shown is the concentration of inducing molecule (aTc) added to each culture. Box plots show the median and upper and lower quartiles; whiskers show 1.5 times the interquartile range; n = 384 per genotype. (D) Data in (C) normalized to the growth of the YJM975 strain expressing the non-targeting control gRNA. Growth is in fluconazole without the addition of radicicol (black) or with radicicol (+Hsp90i; red). The concentrations of inducing molecule (aTc) added to each culture are (left to right) 1000 ng/μL, 500 ng/μL, 250 ng/μL, 125 ng/μL, and 62.5 ng/μL. Data shown are mean and s.e.m. (E) Absolute change in allele effect for Hsp90-modified variants in haploinsufficient genes, essential but not haploinsufficient genes, or all other genes, as indicated. Buffered interactions are shown at left (green) and potentiated interactions at right (purple). Box plots show the median and upper and lower quartiles; whiskers show 1.5 times the interquartile range; p values by two-sample t test; n as indicated. (F) Fraction of Hsp90-interacting gene products amongst all human genes, divided in quintiles by increasing gnomAD pLOF score (blue) and amongst genes haploinsufficient in embryonic stem cells (grey).
